job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working from him, good benefits, PTO, sick time, holiday pay.
cons: Management can’t decide on what their standards are. There is a lot of critique within this job a lot of the time, that’s not something that I was really prepared for when I excepted this job. A big part of this job is making calls to students, helping students go through a presentation of basically about their program, interest and the school. Then you know getting them Registered for school and all that stuff. But the part that I wasn’t told about when I was hired is all of the critiquing within the workplace you’re constantly critiqued every day all the time by everybody. So if you’re not interested in something like that, I would not recommend this job to you , you also have some thing called mentor meetings where they literally listen to your phone calls because your phone calls are recorded as well as your zoom meeting calls. They request that you record a couple of zoom meetings a week and then send them to your mentor so that they can review them. It’s really stressful if that’s some thing that you might be uncomfortable with. They request that you have a certain amount of call time every day which, as of right now what I’ve been told is having at least two hours per day in call time and the zoom time. and it having a certain amount of zoom meetings/information tours every week as well but basically, the information tours are just giving students information about the school, financial aid, cost of school, their program interest.

review_title: Penny pinching real estate company first, art school second
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: The place is run like the worst of a family own business combined with the worst of a corporation. Someone with the right mindset could weave their way through and make a decent living here, but you'll have to be nasty to people.
cons:
There is no culture of family or long term employment here - you have to fight for yearly cost of living salary increases and if you want more than 2 weeks of vacation you have to give up a salary increase. Everyone gets squeezed in every way, and they would prefer you quit than to earn a reputation of paying their employees well. 

Be tough when you negotiate your salary, after you're locked in it is extremely difficult to get more than a 5% raise - and that will take a significant addition to your responsibilities.

There is a crazy amount of financial micromanagement with nearly no oversight over anything else. What people can get away with is crazy in terms of using equipment and resources for their own personal gain, while getting a critically needed sub $100 component ordered could take months.

job_title: Lab Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Supervisors and customer-facing employees were great to work with.  Very rewarding to help difficult topics click with students.  Access to expensive software and carte blanche to develop skills with it.
Depending on supervisor, may be able to work on personal projects during slow hours.
cons:
In attempts to standardize and break down silos, they tried to force very different teams into the same square holes.
Managers had far too many direct reports to manage effectively, in multiple buildings across the city. 
Raises above baseline pay were rare and not related to any kind of objective or documented performance review.
Payroll had high churn and often made mistakes, especially at the beginning and end of semesters.
One-on-one tutoring was eliminated, and headcount in workshops (group tutoring) pushed hard, to reduce costs.  The lab techs are often expected to pick up the slack as wildly underpaid tutors.
Position is classified as "part time" because you're unemployed during breaks.  The highest base pay for a tech position is lower across the year than a full-time job at SF minimum wage.

review_title: You do not want to work here
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: My position itself is extremely rewarding. I work with a great staff in an artistic educational setting in an urban environment. The actual work is engaging, challenging, and stimulating and definitely not routine.
cons: The Executive Office is the biggest con. There is absolutely no positive reinforcement, credit for ones work, or even a consistent and balanced approach to management. This COULD be the coolest place to work--an art school in San Francisco--but the Executive Office goes out of its way to make it as miserable as possible. There's a ridiculous pre-1980s  dress code (no jeans, no visible tattoos, etc...), many of the buildings are not up to code, the office furniture looks like it was dragged out of a dumpster, and the raises are paltry and not nearly enough to keep up with the cost of living. Also, from the top down, a finger-pointing, blame-game culture is nurtured and empowered, rather than a productive "problem-solving" culture. They also treat the staff like naughty little children who just want to get away with something instead of as grown professionals who just might have something to offer. The Executive Office also is extremely nepotistic, so most from the director position on up are complete incompetent morons who take credit for the work done by anyone beneath while perpetuating an abusive and punitive environment. Elisa Stephens' dismal 13% approval rating (can you find a lower rating than that?) says it all.

review_title: 4 years of service and hard work = the axe
job_title: Academic Administrator in San Francisco, CA
pros: The last department I worked for is what made me stay. Being around a lot of creative thinkers. Other than than nothing much.
cons: When I first started at the Academy I was an Executive Assistant to probably one of the most demanding, inappropriate, unprofessional, and crazy Department Directors in the school.  I powered through 2 years of hell in that position before I made a lateral move to another department.  The second department I work for was new and growing. I helped to organize and build that deparment from the ground up.  The people I worked with made all the hard work worth it. The President told me once over drinks I was one of the most valued Administrative Assistants in the university and then I was laid off with no warning.  To add insult to injury  I recieve a call on a Friday morning at 8:30 from HR asking me to come in for a meeting at 4pm. I was told there was nothing to be prepared for. No one in my department was aware of what was going on, not even the Director who was out of the country.  When I got there I was laid off because of the dwindling student numbers.  I was given 2 weeks pay as severance for 4 years of work! I recieved more when I left a family owned retail businesses!  There is absolutely no respect for hardworking and loyal employees.

job_title: Financial Aid Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Access to academy things such as sports, galleries, shows, exhibits. Shuttle system to take you to all the different buildings around campus.

Great manager. Work in an environment where you are not micromanaged. Do job at your own pace.

Co-workers are great. First job where I can actually say all my co-workers are intelligent. 

Pay is pretty good over-all.
cons:
Benefits don't kick in for 90 days. That is a lot of time without health insurance.

Originally was salary, but moved to hourly due to university not wanting to increase our pay.

Work near fisherman's wharf. If you miss the shuttle that takes you there, be prepared to either uber or walk.

Bare minimum in terms of anything for employees. No free food or drinks.

Outdated communications. No computer telephone, no intra-office chat. If you need to get ahold of someone you either have to email or call. 

Friend was fired for unusual reason without any warning.

Not great work-life balance. Between commuting and working, I spend nearly 13 hours of my day getting to work, working and getting home.

Required late day everyweek where we work 11AM-8PM. Often get left alone and isn't really necessary as many people East coast don't answer their phone when its 10+PM.

review_title: Great place to expand your skills, but really no room to advance.
job_title: 3D Animation/VFX Lab Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros: You get to use all the software that is available to students, so you can work on your portfolio while getting paid. Immediate supervisors are fantastic people. Helping students find solutions to problems gives you Satisfaction at the end of the day.
cons: Some of the teachers talk down to you. They make you feel like your 7 years old and act like you do not know what you are doing and I am in my late 30 and I was in Management for 7 years. Upper management that actually runs the school seems like a joke on a weekly basis. No benefits, no incentive to want to stay. Budget cutting seems to be a norm for a school that advertises to be top of the line. I felt very disposable and there were at least 4 times I almost packed up and left.

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: The new director seems to really care about the students and the school and trying to work towards better processes.
cons:
Serious micro-management environment created by managers.  Warning: this is not an "admissions rep or counselor" position.  This is a full-on SALES job minus the perks of a sales job, like commission.  Management will spend their days listening to your calls and counting how many calls you have made just like a sales position would. You are expected to call students a million times and essentially convince them to apply to the school.  You are evaluated based on number applications you get even though most student drop out of this school anyways.  
The environment appears to be about the student at first, but you soon realize they are just considered numbers.  Even if you know a student cannot afford to attend the school or will not be able to pay off loans, you are encouraged to push them to apply and register anyways.  
Most employees in this department don't stay more than a few months once they realize they are doing a sales job.

review_title: Depends on what department you work in
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: I worked there for 8 years up until Dec. 30 2014 and had amazing co workers. I learned a lot of new skills to apply to other jobs. When one person who was causing trouble wasn't there the atmosphere in the office was wonderful. Helping people was the best part of the job.
cons: Management in my old dept. was horrible it got a little better or so we all thought. But then we realized that this person was only getting things in the office for them selves and saying it was for us. They dont care about the needs of the employees even though they tell you that they do. They give you great reviews and then dont listen to you when something is being pinned on you by another co worker and you have plenty of proof. Too many ups and downs in this one dept. No room for growth at all in that dept. maybe others but not mines.

job_title: Academic Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: This place was so dysfunctional so the only positive about my experience there were the people I worked with.
cons:
This was hands down one of the worst places I have ever worked.  If I could give AAU zero stars I would. They treat their students and employees terribly.  Any time I tried to help students I was scolded for, "caring too much." The turnover is constant so students are constantly getting new advisors.  This means students are stuck with advisors who aren't familiar with programs and policies.  

The managers that run the advising team are incompetent and have no experience in advising.  Keeping your head down and your mouth shut is what is most praised.  Regardless if a practice is immoral you are expected to follow with no questions asked. This was most difficult for me because I did not become an advisor so I could turn into a sceezy salesman.  

AAU is known for targeting young, vulnerable and naive students.  Admissions reps are not upfront about the cost and that your financial aid will run out before you can finish your degree.  Even after failing out they will force you to call students over and over again to beg them to come back.  It is not surprising that their turnover rate is so high and that the school is failing.

DO NOT WORK HERE OR GO TO SCHOOL HERE! BEWARE!

job_title: Office of the Registrar in San Francisco, CA
pros: They tend to hire people with little to no experience, so if you're facing homelessness because you can't get an entry level job, this may be a better option than living on the streets, but it's questionable.
cons: Where to begin? This company has at atmosphere of fear wafting through the offices and hallways. The university is for-profit, so while you're working you know that you are working toward screwing students out of exorbitant amounts of money without providing the vast majority of them with anything they can use later in life. The employees are a mix of "lifers", people caught in the trap that is AAU politics until they die of stress-related illnesses, and extremely burned out entry level workers. There are secrets everywhere and you can't trust anyone, because they might rat you out to management and you will get chewed out at best, fired, or made to feel so horrible about yourself you quit because life is just to short to work in such a terrible place. Honestly, if you are reading this and think that you may be an exception to the rule, I'm telling you now, you won't be. Turn around and run. Work at a minimum wage job or deliver food or beg on the side of the road before working for AAU. Life is precious, and whatever AAU is offering you absolutely isn't worth it.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: I took free online classes during my years working for AAU in an entry-level position. I built my portfolio and was able to get a professional job as a result. My boss was a warm and nurturing person who wanted the best for her employees. There are motivated and talented students who can be very inspiring to work with, especially those paying their own way.
cons: A stereotypical corporate nightmare. All employees are treated as cogs in the machine, not as people. Everyone who works there is always stressed out, jaded and resentful. Gaining new students is clearly the primary (and secondary and tertiary) goal of the business, not so much educating the students they already have.  Upper management is filled with political animals who are motivated to steal resources from other departments rather than work with what they have and focus on improving their own dept. Because money comes before education, classes in most depts. are aimed at the lowest common denominator, and there are many rich, entitled, ignorant and unqualified students to deal with and help graduate.

job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: The students are from all over the world and that is magic in itself. The hours are flexible, if one wants to freelance or has other work, that can be a real plus.
cons: In the time that I have worked here, I have had 7 different heads of my department. Some of the teachers are not qualified to teach as they are hired directly after graduation with no real work experience.They replace seasoned insructors often with less experienced people as to pay the lowest salaries possible. The school cuts ones hours short so they do not have to pay benefits.There is no respect or recognition for a job well done.One is only informed if they have done something wrong.

review_title: Fosters complacency and a bare-minimum work force.
job_title: Undergraduate Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros: For former sales people, it's nice to have a high base salary--keep in mind though, working in education means no commission. To offset, the company offers up to a 10% raise and guaranteed title change after one year of employment. The job is very simple if you can stand being on the phone all day, every day. The benefits are average. Managers excluded, the work place is sociable.
cons:
-Very minimal opportunities for upward mobility (1/70)
-An extremely politicized and bureaucratic company--there's favorites, there's forms filled out in triplicate, everything must be okayed by the president. 
-there is 0 incentive to work hard. People who make exactly 60 calls/day and fill out their forms correctly can get higher raises than those who beat their quotas by 200%
-dull, dull, cubicle 9-5. It gets old real fast. For the vast majority of the workforce, this is a transitional job: everyone's sucking it up long enough to find a better gig.

job_title: Data Entry in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Good starting salary plus they raise the salary pretty much every year of your stay.
- Friendly co-workers
- Good benefits like 401k, some free units at the school, etc.
- Nice Christmas party with free food and cocktails
cons:
- Some superiors can be that - "superiors" - a lot of them are snooty and unapproachable
- Our director was a crazy lady: when you call in sick, she would only say "okay" then slams the phone down and cut you off while you're still trying to explain your situation. Wow. 
- Overworked, underpaid. No Christmas bonus but the free food and open bar. Take advantage of that, people.
- You literally see a lot of unhappy office workers in this school just trying to survive. I got out of there as quickly as I could just like Sophia A. Go figure.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros: This is surely a good place
cons: This place offers low compensation

review_title: It's time to match the processes and metrics to the mission
job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: The salary is good, benefits are adequate, and we use Salesforce, which is an incredible tool.
cons: So many people in this position are actively looking for work elsewhere. They recruit passionate people who care about inspiring students for careers in art and design, and then treat us like drones or automatons. Attention needs to be paid to the culture - if the admissions reps are dissatisfied and feel unsupported and unappreciated, and they're the face of the school to prospective students, that has a direct impact on the school's enrollment and employee turnover.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros:
This may differ by department, but you will meet the best people you could ever work with. Everybody is open, respectful, and nice. They make this place bearable. 

Depending on where you work, the location could also be a plus. Transportation benefits are nice, I guess, but they're also standard at every workplace. I usually leave by the time I am supposed to. I don't work 12 hour days.
cons:
This is very long, hence the list. The cons far outweigh the pros. Remember, this is a toxic for-profit university! 

- The obvious point: it's more about money than the students.
- Turnover rate is very high -- huge red flag. 
- You are seen as a cog in a machine. Your performance is measured constantly, but you receive minimal support from upper management for the work you do. Other places do this well; constant support and flexibility. This is not one of those places. 
- Extreme micromanagement about performance. 
- Absolutely no room for growth. 
- Lack of transparency re: salaries and business practices.
- No financial support. We are expected to buy everything ourselves. We don't get tea or coffee. 
- No work culture. No fun. We come in, we work, we go home. Everybody is jaded.
- No communication at all.

review_title: Company values? Company values itself above all else.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Excellent peers and middle managers eager to go the extra mile and do a great job. Great team with which employees and middle managers solve complicated, often politically charged problems. Decent benefits package and hours.
cons: Company values? Company values itself only, not the people who who work for it. Narcissistic upper managers, VPs, and ineffective HR department join forces to protect each other as often (and it is often) as needed. Massive turnover as a result. Inability or lack of desire (probably a little bit of both) to make positive change to work environment or morale. Those at the bottom and in the middle left to do it themselves.

job_title: Lab Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Most Departments are full of cool people with passion for the subjects they teach or support.

From top-down the school has a diverse staff with lots of women and people of color working at almost all levels of management.
cons:
A lot of people making business decisions are artists by training with little to no business experience.  Budget process is arcane and archaic - you write an excel doc, present it at a meeting, then write specific orders on triplicate paper forms, which go through approvals of a SINGLE person who probably hasn't ever set foot in your actual school, then get inter-officed a paper purchase order.... its... crazy.  

Never seen a place more hostile to the advancement of staff.

job_title: Academic Administrator in San Francisco, CA
pros: NOTHING - STAY AWAY.  I'm surprised that this "University" is still in business.  Elisa Stephens and her frienemy cronies use AAU as a personal resource and are entirely money focused.  They do not invest in their workforce and skimp on needed materials, students are viewed as walking money bags, and employee abuse is rampant.  If you see a good review of AAU it's from a "favorite" who is stupid enough to be easily molded by the President's office and cruel enough to indiscriminately attack anyone who they perceive to be in their way.
cons: EVERYTHING - I wish I could give AAU negative stars.  I started looking for a new job on my 2nd day of employment.  While I was at AAU I continually reached out to HR to report employee abuses and was given a vague promise that the work environment would be improved and to just be patient.  HR was more concerned about protecting Elisa Stephens than improving an abusive work environment.

review_title: I wish I could give them negative stars!
job_title: Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Your amazing, talented coworkers (who will all quit before you do) and the experience you can add to your resume
cons:
-EVERYTHING, seriously. I STILL get anxiety when I think about my time here. 
-Sadly, every single person here is miserable, depressed, overworked, undervalued, overwhelmed and you will quickly notice and understand why if you move forward. 
-There is NO academic or advising aspects to the admissions representative role this is purely a SALES position. 
-The entire job consists of making sales calls/replying to emails and hoping you get applications and registrations
-If you do not produce you will be micromanaged until you feel suffocated. 
-Favoritism is rampant and your few coworkers that do well will receive special treatment. 
-Management does not care for the students like you do, all they see is $$$$ (It is for-profit education) 
-If you are looking for a long term career, great environment, mentally challenging role, flexibility, equality, really care about students, want a 401K, want good benefits DO NOT take this toxic position. And if you do...good luck.

review_title: Excellent--they let me be creative in my teaching style if I produce results
job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: I love that they let me be who I am when I teach. I follow the syllabus closely, but teach it in my own way. I like that they don't force you to teach a certain way because it is beneficial to the students to let my professional experience dictate some of the course material.
cons: I feel like regardless of how much I put in to this position (my heart and soul) I will always be part-time. Even teaching 5 classes, spending countless hours grading, and working on creative lesson plans, I will only get paid the $50 for the time I'm spending in the class. I'd love to be salaried and taken better care of in terms of sick-pay, vacation, etc.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you're the type of "professional" who wants to get away with doing nothing half of the time and then doing a terrible job (when there actually is something to be done) the other half of the time, then this organization is for you.  For anyone who knows how to look the other way and keep their mouth shut, one can do "well" here.
cons: The overall attitude here is terrible, and it spreads like a virulent infection to newcomers.  If you approach a new position at this school with aspirations of success, expecting better things to follow, you will quickly encounter the doom and gloom which underlies the false platitudes of all the staff.  Then, once you first face the indifference and and elitist perception of the upper administration, your own sense of hopelessness is inevitable.  Departments not only do not communicate with each other, but actively undermine each others efforts and blame failures anywhere but internally.  It often seems that no one knows what's going on...

review_title: Most employees here want to go elsewhere or are not qualified to find work elsewhere.
job_title: Administrator, Admissions Operations in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great location in downtown San Francisco. Okay pay and benefits, especially if you have a degree. Some departments - and managers and better than others. If you are lucky you might have a decent experience, at least with your co-workers and direct supervisor. One perk - free admission to SFMOMA.
cons: This is not a true University, but a company that sells education related products and services. As someone who spent ample time working in higher education, I was appalled at the outdated practices employed to administer this school. The upper management is notorious for being inconsistent, unfair, and having poor communication skills. This place runs on a culture of fear where employees must never ask questions or make suggestions but blindly accept every edict that comes down and grovel at the feet of middle and upper management. Turn over is HIGH. Employees are often unhappy. Worst of all it is common for those who are sick or injured to transfered to an unattractive job or be let go.

review_title: Online education here is not the best place to work
job_title: Content Editor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Most of my actual work isn't so bad. It's content-driven, educational, compelling, and relevant. The people I work with are amazing, especially the middle management folks.
cons: The people who head the online learning department have tasked the production with so much meaningless busy work that has no pedagogical merit that the day-to-day experience of working here no longer has much meaning or redemption. Rules seem arbitrary, and they are almost always instituted with no warning. We are often asked to do "more, more, more" with fewer and fewer staff and in less time.

job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Creative and talented faculty make for an interesting workplace.
Students have a great deal of support, especially international students.
There are many excellent instructors FT and PT.
cons:
Executives do not value enough the expertise of teachers or understand needs of adjuncts and longstanding faculty.
The school needs a higher academic standard instead of so many promises about jobs at the end of the degree.
A blindness when it comes to educational outcomes. Full-time teachers work so hard to create and implement a solid curriculum only to have it completely undermined by very poor executive judgment and naive and selfish decision making. The school wants to make money off of students, especially foreign ones.

review_title: This place is a joke -- A really unfunny one
job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I was the Administrative Assistant of a relatively small department which meant that I rarely was even IN the office. Since one Director worked online and the other Director only came onsite 3 days a week if they weren't there I wasn't there.  The best part was NO ONE NOTICED! Which is pretty much the reason I stayed on for 3+ years.  

I did also manage to convince my boss that I deserved a higher-than-usual raise -- which I got so hey...that was pretty great!


Besides that I did think the Spring Show was impressive each year  (when it didn't have to be torn down 3 days after it was put up because the President needed to show off her car collection in the same space) and the holiday parties were open bar....that was about it.
cons: Besides the fact that all this school cares about is how much money they can drain from international students, upper management is threatened by any instructor that is super well liked and they pay those instructors next to nothing...what's not to love?

review_title: WORST PLACE TO WORK! RUN AWAY!
job_title: Accountant in San Francisco, CA
pros: The students are really wonderful!
cons: Please don't be fooled by Academy or University in the title. This is a S-corporation owned by 2 family members and runs for the sake of money only. The HR is there to hire and fire people only nothing more. Their employee break room does not even have windows or air vent! You probably will not get paid on time 0r correctly because their back office is overworked. Just ask some of their employees how many times they had to get their checks corrected. You might think they management might hear but nope! They usually hire as a temp or part time to avoid paying your unemployment insurance or any benefits. Even if you get hired as regular employee you will not see any benefits for the first 3 months of working there - that is if you survive 3 months! Their employee turnover is the highest that I know of. Just save yourself and don't even apply for a job there. If you surf craigslist often enough you will see same job ad repeated in several weeks of intervals - meaning they hired and fired someone within few weeks.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
If you are desperate for a job, go ahead. It is not hard to get a job from this sinking ship. 
Flexibility to work from home because there isn’t much you can actually do, nothing happens at this place.
One big pro, you will learn about what is the unethical practice in every possible way and what not to be in your future career.
cons:
Full of ignorant racists and egoistic bully. You manager would insult you on your very first day at work.

No one cares about this place, people clock in and out for the pay checks. You might get great coworkers because everyone hates this place.

Mediocre salary and benefits, very limited growth. Your mental health means nothing to the management. They care about one thing and only -  easy money!

Full of politics, and if you are a do-nothing but good at being sycophantic yes-man, you will go far here. However, this school is a sinking ship and notorious in the industry. One more lawsuit will possibly break it apart. So even if you are looking for an easy job, think twice!

No one cares about your values or contributions, just smile and nod to your boss, working at the Academy of Art is not that hard.

review_title: A Stepping Stone to the Next Best Thing
job_title: Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Salary is sufficient to the cost of living. The location is great. Your co-workers are great people...once you are allowed to talk to them. In all honesty, this place is perfect if you are looking to build your resume or save some money with a decent salary.
cons: The amount of micro-management is ridiculous...almost suffocating. It is to the point where the managers will chide you for long bathroom breaks, 2 minutes over the 15 minutes break and chatting with your neighbor. This is a strict call center where you will be judged on the amount of phone calls you made, how many students you registered and how you 'engaged' a student in their discussion about education. You can tell that most employees are terrified that they will lose their jobs because they called out sick or that their numbers weren't high enough.

review_title: Don't expect fair treatment, expect a private company who does what it wants , how it wants, regardless of common sense.
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Depending on who you know, you can do well. If you do your job and keep your head down at all times, you will be o.k.
If you are a good socializer, say "Yes"  to everything, and hook up  with the right people, you will  probably get promoted. If you mention you went to the same college or university as the president or an Ivy league, you will be valued higher and compensated higher.
cons: Individuals who get promoted to management are often very young and green. Usually hired form within, with little or no experience, and manage people sometimes 10+ years older than they are. Theses managers lack maturity, impartiality and the experience of how their decisions impact their employees in the longer term.

review_title: If you are a robot, you are welcome to here.
job_title: Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros: close to the public transportation, some cool teachers and students. There is a $200 reward for current employee to introduce a friend if he gets hired here. It is great to get this money for punishing someone you doesn't like by throwing him in.
cons: HR policy or benefits are just a picture in the frame. Please do not try to fight for your rights, just quit quietly. Never get approved to take vacation days when you are in need of it. Worked on holidays but did not receive paid day-off instead. Push you do over time work or work from home on weekends without paid. Managers do not know what they are talking about. A lot of practice do not make sense but you are not allowed to give suggestion. Talented co-workers will not stay here longer than 6 months, maybe even 3 months? No Complement, only Criticism. Every much micromanagement plus misleading. You are always monitored, good to say like a FBI, bad to say like a prisoner, go figure. You are just waiting for a day or a reason to get out of here.

review_title: the cons outweigh the pros - not worth the 60k
job_title: Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-I learned that I could have a successful career in sales 
-My manager was one of the few great people in this organization
-They pay well for a position where little to no experience is required
-The admissions building in fisherman's wharf has a great view of the golden gate bridge
cons:
-9am-6pm 3 days a week, 11am-8pm 2 days a week - absolutely no flexibility or exceptions here
-very strict about sick time and vacation
-expect to sit at your desk all day making calls to high school students who don't know why they are on your list
-this is a business, do not except anyone to act as though it is an institution that puts students and education first 
-the school has a pretty negative  reputation that you will have to fight on most calls 
-management cares a lot of your performance (how many applications and registrations you get) but do not goal accordingly so it challenging to stay motivated 
-overall negative and toxic work environment - I found it really hard to remain positive in an environment where no one wanted to be there and constantly spoke ill of the organization 
-little to no opportunities to advance and get promoted

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: If it wasn't for the amazing people who work at and attend this school I probably would have stopped beating this dead horse a long time ago.  That and the pleasure of being around the artistically minded keep me treading water.
cons: I can't count the amount of times I've heard an Academy employee talking about how they were lead down the garden path, cheated out of benefits or treated poorly by management.  The response is generally "Oh, thats just the Academy way."  It seems to be common knowledge that the Academy is a lackluster employer who is more concerned with filling the pockets of the elite than providing a quality work environment or producing quality artists.  It's a pity.

review_title: Customer Service - Stay AWAY from this place
job_title: Customer Service in San Francisco, CA
pros: Decent pay, amazing coworkers. Blah blah blah I need 20 words minimum but there are no other pros to list.
cons: Everything else. Literally. The job is monotonous and they treat you like children. The few responsibilities you are given are monitored and scrutinized to no end. There is little to no room for growth and the only way to do so is by brown nosing your way to the top. If you want to sit in a cubicle for 8 hours a day and take maybe 2 hours(if you're lucky) worth of phone calls during that time, this is the job for you. Just know those other 6 hours will be spent staring at 3 walls and a computer screen trying not to doze off. And if you dare try to keep yourself awake by talking to anyone around you or looking at your phone be prepared for the consequences!!

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Good pay, considering the work. Standard 8 hour work day with a 1 hour lunch, but the work is easy, and boring. Everything is formulaic and well-documented, and techniques (in general) are applicable in many other industries.
Employees can take 1 class a semester for free (excluding books).
Co-workers are great, they're all friendly, social, fun - and often overqualified.
Great resume experience for your next position.
cons:
Micromanagement is the biggest problem here, unlikely to change because it's a top-down dilemma.
Rules, rules, rules. There are way too many minor infractions that have nothing to do with the job that one can incur. They are easy to follow, but ridiculous.
Employees in my department signed a paper stating that work performance would not be taken into consideration for promotions and raises. Thusly, employees that should be promoted often are not, and management favors advancing their friends. For such a large company, so bizarre.

review_title: Amazing people but executives that don't care
job_title: Student Services in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Great people work here!
The pay is pretty competitive and there is potential for a raise each year.
Fun holiday party.
cons:
No potential for advancement -- it's a job, not a career.
The dress code is ridiculous -- slacks/ties for men, "business casual" for women. This would be fine if we weren't working for an art school in San Francisco (a casual attire start-up hub).
Holiday schedule -- You would think that working for a school would grant you time off, but not at AAU. Only 7 holidays + 10 vacation days + 2 floating holidays + 6 sick days. Public schools have way more time off.

job_title: Pre-Admissions Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: I have an amazing team and manager which makes my job quite enjoyable. Working with students and their families is really rewarding. When it's 6 o'clock, you leave work at work, you don't have to worry about checking emails/answering the phone. Pretty easy and not very stressful. The pay is quite good and it's a good entry level job for people seeking employment in higher education. Benefits are decent.
cons: Can be quite repetitive and even boring some days. I don't feel very challenged. I also feel there's sometimes a very negative energy that lingers, perhaps because we are a for profit institution and numbers are important, it seems like it gets people really down. I personally dread the outbound calls that we have to make, I feel like I'm bothering people. I don't like that I feel like I'm being watched.

job_title: Administration in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Many of the students and instructors here are a joy to work with. As someone who is "artsy", but not quite an artist yet, it's incredibly inspiring to be surrounded with such creative talent. Working here will give you valuable exposure to all of the art fields.

There is also an option to take a course for free each semester (though I never had the opportunity to do that). The location in downtown SF can't be beat.
cons: Being underpaid, and just feeling like a cog in a machine. I just showed up to do my job every day, and never felt that there was any interest from management to make things more efficient or giving me more responsibility. I also never felt any kind of "team" mindset while working here -- everyone seems pretty independent.

review_title: Save yourselves, the ship is going down fast
job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Location, fellow instructional staff and directors can be a joy to work with. Obligatory "satisfaction of seeing a new generation learn and grow their skills."
cons: Administration cares about nothing beyond profit. Policies are shouted down from the top, with no one to bring issues to. They WILL lie, cheat, and steal to prevent you from having a choice. Communication stops at the director level, not that the directors aren't trying - they just go unheard. Schedules get crunched any time the Academy faces any legal battles. Part-time staff are lured in with "competitive pay" and "flexible hours" which are neither competitive nor flexible, and often get in the way of taking on other work - which they expect you to do. Posted hourly wages are ONLY for in-class hours, everything else - aka 75% of the job- is on your own time or compensated at minimum wage. But if you spend more than an hour or two a week - you'll definitely get pinged about it. All $30 worth of time.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Morgan Hill, CA
pros: Good pay & benefits. That's about it. It's a business not a school. It's a full time sales position. They will sell you a dream.
cons: The pay and benefits are not worth the time invested. You will do NOTHING the in the job description you are hired for. You will work every Saturday. 6 days a week. 3 of your weekly days will be 11-8pm shift. (So all day). This is a high pressure sales position and you are not a counselor by any means. Students don't start next semester or quarter, they want them to start tomorrow regardless if they are accepted, school started, they don't have the money etc.. Part of your job responsibilities will be to sell a 100k loan to single moms or families where their kids can't even write a 200 word essay and have below 2.0 gpa. I worked here for 2.5 years, exceeded expectations and every goal put in front of me. They will say, "this job is not for everybody". They are right, it's only for people who are willing to sell their soul, otherwise I don't know how they sleep at night.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Great managers working with you in your department
Ability to help students and make a difference in their experience
Opportunity to learn about equipment beyond your comfort zone
cons: Bureaucracy ruins experience - managers can value and respect you all they want, but they can't do anything to show it. Raises, continued employment, and opportunities depend on someone who knows nothing about your day-to-day workflow, and who may not even ever meet you.

review_title: Working as an ESL teacher/ESL support teacher
job_title: ESL Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Decent pay (for ESL), opportunities for professional development.  Interesting job.  I teach EAP classes (English for Art Purposes), which are basically academic ESL courses with art vocabulary and assignments added.  I also teach ESL support, which means that I sit in on a variety of different classes and help the international students succeed by making sure that they understand what is going on, what their assignments are, as well as reviewing class material with them.
cons: One of the major challenges of being an ESL support teacher is not the actual job itself, but dealing with the teachers whose classes you sit in on.  Most of them are very professional, make clear what they expect of you and are easy to get along with.  But there are a few which might put your people skills to the test.

job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great faculty, abslutely qualified instructors and lecturers. They are legit. If you are a part-timer you'll be fine. No one will bother you, they let you teach. Any criticism of academics you read are largely from loser students who were not good enough or delusional about their skills. Ignore those reviews. Ask an A student how their experience was and
cons: It's run like an organized crime family. There's one boss, the president. There are capos (captains) whose job it is is to catch you doing things wrong. They will not hesitate to call you out for anything. There are the lieutenants who work under the capos. They too look for mistakes. If you're a full-timer you have to keep your head down. They are looking, and they will find you, and they will get you. Toxic treatment of FT staff. If you're tough, you can survive.

review_title: Crooked Administration +  Scientifically Managed Curriculum  =  Anti-Education ÷ Marginally Competent Faculty
job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are a lot of people with varied skills and interests that end up working for the Academy of Art. Being employed there allows for an opportunity to commiserate with these people. Some can also inspiration when working with students.
cons: This is a higher-ed institution that is run top-down from the executive office, the irony of a trade school being that there is no such thing as career development here. Students in high-impact majors are recruited via unethical standards and practices, the cost of which is passed down to the staff and faculty (not just instructors) as students are held in school with wildly differing expectations. Nightmarish politics when dealing with underpaid department administrators jockeying for position. Little in the way of benefits. Compensation for instructors is slightly higher than adjunct faculty at public schools, but is paid hourly and does not include curriculum development (read: hours and hours of unpaid labor).

job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: The job is low-stress with creative atmosphere. I have great coworkers. This position is perfect if you're looking for a day job while you pursue your dreams in the career you want outside of your day job. I'm not bringing my work home with my at all. When I clock out, I mentally clock out of work too. I never bring home any drama from work or any projects and the department is very strict on allowing us to use our off time (breaks, lunches, off-the-clock) as OFF time.
cons: This position is not a route to build a career unless you would like to work in school admissions

review_title: There's a lot of room for growth,  and the staff is amazing, the staff that I know.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: I really enjoy my job and love my peers. I'm constantly being challenged and busy so I'm never bored.  I appreciate the opportunity for continued growth. I've learned what you put into your career is what you get out of it, and my hard work has definitely been noticed. It's nice to know, that students that have a passion for Art, are the ones that excel and I'm part that,  indirectly. The shuttles and locations are also a huge plus.
cons: The benefits are great for employee only coverage, but are a little expensive to cover dependants.  That's all I can think of.

job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: I enjoyed working with all of the passionate students. They are all very dedicated, and do great work. Some need help with motivation, but these are always a great group. Also, excellent language support staff.
cons:
The biggest challenge for me was the curriculum. It is more designed for online students, and doesn't include assignments. I spent more time than I expected developing curriculum, although they have started paying for time spent  outside of the classroom. 

It was also difficult to get these design-focussed students to learn more complex coding like JavaScript and PHP, especially with a short two classes dedicated to each.

review_title: Good for gaining experience in Higher Ed, but awful company culture.
job_title: Admission and Student Services in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good place to gain experience working in higher education if you are just starting your career. Awesome employees that tend to leave quickly due to poor company culture. Some perks to attend school events and great holiday party.
cons: Does not value employees. Took away 401k matching, minimal vacation and sick days, poor medical/dental/vision coverage - especially if you have children! Works employees to the ground but gives the bare minimum if they can be called benefits at all. All shots are called by Elisa Stephens who has fired anyone, even those who dedicated their entire career to the company, as soon as they stop following her orders.

job_title: Human Resources in San Francisco, CA
pros: Depending on which building your in the location is great! Some of my co-workers are great friends of mine now even after I left the Academy.
cons: When I first started I was really excited to be apart of this organization; I was sadly mistaken. Eventually, I was never excited to go to work. There was little to no coaching if any employee made a mistake, it would instantly lead to a write up or termination. High turnover in many of the departments and the benefits package was not the best. Also, the 401k match is not guaranteed each year. They make you feel like you are walking on eggshells when you go to work and that you should "fear" management.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Really enjoy teaching the students and being an instructor
My direct boss is wonderful and really helped me with maternity leave and being a new mom. (not reflective of all departments, however)
Faculty have real pride in the work that students create
Very diverse student body
cons:
Lots of politics and bureaucratic nonsense
HR is difficult when it comes to salary negotiation (like, really difficult)
Unclear organization tree of overall company 
Not strong enough at getting rid of ineffective faculty or those who work for personal agendas vs that of the students.
Cut the Faculty Development office, which was a huge boon to supporting faculty and helping them learn to become better instructors
Online Ed is a hot mess

job_title: Lab Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- great to be around some really talented and driven individuals, that goes for faculty and students.

- able to take 1 free class per semester

- easy in
cons:
- lack of communication among teams.  Lack of training/effort/offers for teaching the rest of us supplemental IT-related solutions

- Just because I don't brown-nose all day in the offices upstairs doesn't mean I can't more greatly contribute to the department.  I feel like a sugar-coated wall exists between  management/supervisiors and us technicians.  It's almost like a social class system.

- 2 years, hard working, great with students, any signs of a raise ever? Sorry.  The most you'll get is that they "are looking out for us" in case a teaching or workshop opportunity opens up.

review_title: Work study jobs are difficult to get if not proactive
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: I convinced my boss to let me split telecommute after my second semester, so I only came in to the office twice a week. Since I did work study throughout grad school, I didn't have to take out as many high cost loans.
cons: Made me feel jaded watching how students' fees were used by the school on frivolous programs that the students had no say in. Very strange and archaic running of programs by school management, especially compared with the rich, open democratic student led organizations at my undergrad.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: A lot of people here say it's a good first job in San Francisco, and that's true. In my department, we were able to lean on each other a lot when things were coming down hard from the senior management.
cons:
Where to begin.

The university is very much for-profit, basically funneling public student loan funds and crazy high international student tuition into their coffers.

The senior management is erratic, domineering, inconsistent, and suspicious. The whole environment outside of academics borders on paranoia, constantly worrying about what other departments' true motives are. In my time there, I initially assume it was just paranoia, until I began to see the office politics at work, and realized it was often justified.

From the perspective of management, employees are just cogs to be moved (literally and figuratively) as needed.

job_title: Campus Host in San Francisco, CA
pros: Some nice people. The fact that there were benefits at all for Part Time positions. Management seemed to care about happiness.
cons: Minimum wage. Hired Part-Time and worked Full-time with Part-Time (limited) benefits. Moral issues with the insane amount of money the for-profit, barely accredited school makes off of the students. Witnessed an employee that wasn't management (but thought she was) use the words, "You mess up and I will fire you, do you understand?!" to an older Asian man on his first day as security while she was 'training' him.

job_title: Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Depending on contract you could have a bunch of paid vacation. 
Some departments are a blast to work for. Some!
Opportunity to keep up to date on art and creative technology is at one's fingertips.
cons:
Upper management makes questionable decisions and assigns dual roles to under-qualified and/or mismatched workers to help save pennies, and in the long run only hurts the company.
No raises, not even to keep up with inflation.
No bonuses.
X-mas party is awkward and makes you wonder why the money put towards that event can't be used to give folks a small bonus from time to time in lieu of the celebration.
Underpaid.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Location. Many buildings are in great locations and convenient via public transit
-Easy interview process and easy to get in. Perfect if you a desperate for a job, a recent grad, re-entering the workforce, or lack experience and/or ambition. 
-The possibility to work on unique and interesting projects and events.
cons:
-Toxic, abusive work culture.
-Upper management does not care about employees. 
-Work is demanding and compensation is well below average for the location, which explains the extremely high turnover.
-Company has a negative reputation and is dealing with many lawsuits and bad PR.
-Few opportunities for advancement.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are some very dedicated teachers and staff members here... Unfortunately they are vastly outnumbered and there are so many roadblocks in their way.
cons: AAU is hampered by its president, her unbridled desire for profit above all else, and an incompetent and bureaucratic administrative staff. Departments are pitted against each other as they bid for funding. Support for teachers is lacking, so there's high turnover and low incentive to teach well or be involved. They are constantly in trouble with the city for code violations, and aren't in great standing with several of their accrediting bodies. Students looking for a good art education should be advised to go elsewhere... And job seekers looking for employment should be advised to go elsewhere if they value their sanity and their self-respect.

job_title: Photography Lab Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great opportunities to learn from top educators, amazing students who will most likely become great friends, the ability to use amazing equipment. If you take advantage of all the learning opportunities you will grow a lot as an artist.
cons: Management is completely messed. My reason for leaving was a switch in management. The new management does not care about the students or it’s technicians. They do not appreciate the work that is put in and the paycheck reflects that. They will tell you you get a couples weeks off in between semesters but it’s more like 2 months which is extremely hard financially on an already low paying job.

review_title: The worst mistake I ever made was taking this job
job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you have a strong dislike for yourself, perhaps your esteem is too high or you enjoy being treated like a worthless human being, I would recommend working here.
cons: The worst thing about the place is that there are going to be other nice people like you working there who are in the same horrible place.  Management is incompetent and at the same time nasty.  They talk down to everyone and expect complete submission.  A small comment or opinion about their programs can get you fired or worse, treated poorly for years.

job_title: Online Development in San Francisco, CA
pros: None, do not work here
cons: work here if you want be managed like the communist, with your manager harrassing and discriminating against you all the time for nothing, verbally threatening insubordination for using the bathroom, arriving to your seat 1 minute late after the time you are due into the office, no lunch breaks, being managed by under qualified managers who are put in place due to nepotism, insecure, and want to fire all the qualified persons who do decent work to make herself look better, being force to work under construction site @ office, it goes on and on, work environment not up to code with no kitchen sinks forcing employees to wash dishes in the bathroom, horrible, worse than a concentration camp.

job_title: Undergraduate Student Services Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Everyone who works in the office is very friendly, welcoming and helpful. When I first started everyone was willing to lend a hand.

Software tools that are used in the office to manage student accounts are easy to pick up and after about a month of using them I feel very comfortable.
cons: it is a very policy driven school.Many times the human element is removed from a decision making process and is based on what is stated in the Academy guidlines. The reason this is a con for me is that it doesn't allow for creative problem solving, it can feel robotic at times.

review_title: Admissions Representative at AAU was the worst job I ever had
job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: The locations in San Francisco are in great buildings and interesting parts of the city.   One of the benefits is that you can take classes at AAU, but be forewarned- you will get stuck paying the taxes for the class even if AAU pays for the class tuition.
cons: If you are looking for a supportive work environment, then look elsewhere.  AAU is the opposite of a professional work environment.   Many of the staff were very smart and motivated however the smart ones end up leaving because of the management.  There is a very large turn around and constant hiring for new admissions staff because people are running away and people are getting fired often.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Huge pool of brilliant, talented people encompassing multiple creative professions. Interesting and engaging work is possible.
cons: Culture of fear and politics. Limited opportunity for advancement: internal opportunities rarely advertised (cronyism rules the day). Antiquated management philosophies (somewhere between "9 to 5" and "The Office"). Corporate, "for-profit" ethos trumps real commitment to quality education. Poor compensation.

review_title: Sad Place to Work! Can't Wait to Leave!
job_title: Anonymous in Pittsburg, CA
pros: Your co-workers are unhappy so it gives you someone to vent to. The best departments to work in are Student Affairs and Transfer Department. You will see every other department look miserable.
cons: Where to begin! No room for growth, no raise, we work hard and management received a bump in salary(I won't say any names,) don't ever come in late, just call off, your penalized more for tardiness than calling off. Human Resources is the worst support system ever, don't ever confide in them, get a lawyer! I have interviews lined up and once I get the word, I'm out! please read the reviews from actual employees. I notice that Human Resources writes a lot of these reviews to build there ratings.

review_title: No support when support and communication are needed
job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA

cons: Below market pay for amount of work. Little trust between directors and administration. So-so benefits. No incentive to try harder since there are no merit raises. review_title: Decent pay but environment is unsatisfying.
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Decent pay with higher than normal industry rates in higher education. Great co-workers and some great students and faculty go here. If you do your work, management will leave you alone.
cons: Work environment is daunting. All of my coworkers had a lot of complaints about AAU and how they did not feel like they were respected and how seniority overrides propriety in conflicts. Co workers always complain about how issues are addressed but never resolved. Only 10 days of vacation a year (maximum of 20 overall) and they always want you to work Christmas eve. Be prepared to work like crazy around the start of each semester.

review_title: All the opportunity in the world, if they like you.
job_title: Customer Service in San Francisco, CA
pros: World class city, amazing buildings and architecture. You get the feeling that you are helping someone... Benefits are decent and there's a great holiday party at the end of each year.
cons: Cheap people! They invest in themselves and property and not at all in the employees. Don't do annual reviews, they nit pick and hire people from outside the company without offering opportunities. Don't provide any perks such as coffee or snacks like most thriving businesses.

review_title: Not a place for a career

Senior management within the department I worked in is some of the worst I have ever encountered. If something goes wrong you are berated loudly in front of the entire team. Senior management does not understand or respect your job. Edicts come down in a reactionary manner.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA

Working with student artwork, I always got to do interesting projects.
I had a lot of autonomy. 
I had a good computer workstation.
Access to online course materials. 
I got to have very good work-life balance to take care of my family.

Culture is more of competition than collaboration, intimidation rather than inspiration. 
AAU management never failed to make bad decisions and ignore expert recommendations. 
Terrible morale among staff.

job_title: Photography Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros: The staff & faculty at AAU are outstanding people. And 90% of the time the students are polite and friendly. Fairly high job security.
cons: For the technician position AAU requires a BA degrees and pays barely above minimum wage. Even for full time techs the pay isn't worth it. Turnover is these positions tends be 1-2 years because it's a dead-end. There's also very little opportunity for advancement within a department. I get the impression even the management positions aren't paid adequately.

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros:
The people that i worked with were some of the best people that I have ever met in my life.  I am still in touch with some of the students as well.

The training taught me a lot about the psychology of working with people - which I still use now.  But only for good.
cons: It is little more than a call center set up where one is closely monitored and spied upon. Incredibly  hostile treatment from management.

review_title: Decent experience for an entry level position in Financial Aid Department.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Located in downtown SF. Access to all gyms and basketball courts. Best part of work was my co workers. Benefits are pretty standard. Good office experience. Amazing holiday party.
cons: AAU does not match 401K. Certain blocked off periods for start of new semesters, so you can't request days off. Pay is below average. Too much work and not enough pay. No room for growth. Training is also not adequate.

job_title: Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Location is downtown SF which makes it very accessible via public transit. Admissions department's salary starts out between, 40k - 50k (depends on what management determines from your sales qualifications), which is OK in this economy. Job security is strengthened by the fact this school has VERY DEEP POCKETS. Admissions is strictly an office job, so no manual labor of any sorts.
cons: Admissions is SALES for the company. Advisors are treated like telemarketers whose telephone calls are screened, recorded by trainers and critiqued by management. Salary can be decreased if you don't achieve your (nearly) impossible sales goal. For the first goal of your at this job, you may achieve it, thus increasing your salary to about 50k, but the second term's goal is so unattainable that you are shot down to your base. There is 50-call/daily minimum (whether it's voicemails or whatnot, as long as there is a connection with the other line). In Admissions, management cares only about quantity of students and not quality. Students=Money and they will do anything to make the sale. Some departments (i.e., Student Service) has a salary cap of $65k. If you get higher up the ranks of salary, you are closer to being targeted by management to increase your goal to being impossible. Most people do not last more than 2-3 years.

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: This job pays enough to make a living, which is nice. Not sure if it's worth all the unhappiness of the day to day work though.
cons: AAU has a terrible work environment. Very negative and micromanagey, lots of restrictions on what employees can and can not do, and they make you do things like log your breaks when you're a salaried employee. Very rarely would you ever get an positive feedback, only negative and reactive feedback.

review_title: Its what you make of it...

review_title: The Academy of Art University- good for students not so good for staff.

review_title: A lot of promise neutralized by toxic culture
job_title: Content Editor in San Francisco, CA

Good ideas are snuffed out regularly, and it's hard to stay enthusiastic in such a demotivating environment.

job_title: Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-9-6 (no one texts you after work)
-indirect sales experience
cons:
-your job is to lure people into debt by exploiting their creative dreams
-this is an unethical workplace. you have quality conversations with people and hurt their livelihood by enrolling them into this school
-the curriculum is bad. not sure how they maintain their accredidation

review_title: Layers and Layers of Inefficient Bureaucracy
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: I felt a palpable sense of being able to help some students as they negotiated their way through the system.  There are some very good, genuine people working here.
cons: The top down bureaucracy dictates terms, and it's up to you to deal.  Once you get hired in at one role, it's very difficult to move around or get promoted.  Budgets can arbitrarily change from semester to semester with no explanation.

review_title: Demanding work, no support from upper management
job_title: Pre-Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: AAU does attract some amazing people and they help lift you up in times of distress (which is everyday). Since effective leadership is lacking, the employees have a "swim or drown" way of working. Those who surpass their quotas and stay afloat become very well-versed, professionally attuned, and are going to be superstars at their next position.
cons: There are many instances of reflecting on our actions at AAU and wondering where our moral compass has gone if we are still here day after day despite not agreeing with their business and education practices.

review_title: If you're okay with a high pressured sales job, decent pay, no perks, and mircro-management  ... work here.
job_title: Admission Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-They hire GREAT people. My colleagues were one of the only reasons I could stand this place for a year. I was lucky enough to be placed with one of the best managers there for the majority of my time at AAU.

-Decent pay and standard benefits for new college graduates 

-Decent work/life balance. You come in at 8/9 and leave at 5/6. You leave work at work. 

-Good location in SF. Civic center or Financial District. 

-The concept of the job was good. There were [very few] times that I felt like I was actually helping people.

-You are exposed to a plethora of different industries and facets of art. 
The school is pretty fascinating and cultivates amazing opportunities for its students, IF you have the large amount of funds to finish the program. 

-The one and only perk they provided was one free class each semester that included Adobe Creative Suite for free. 

-Very fun holiday party. Good food, open bar, and great prizes for employees
cons:
-They are not upfront about what the job entails. From getting hired, all the way through the 3 week training, they try to disguise the description of the job to make you think that you're some sort of life counselor. The training pretty much did not train you on anything you had to do on a daily basis. 

-This is a high sales pressured job. Your product? A $100k education in art. All they care about are numbers numbers numbers. 

-Your day to day duties include cold calling, mass emails, harassing people you have already talked to to call you back, and finding ways to stay awake from this painstakingly boring job. 

-You have weekly one on ones with your manager. Every call you make or take is recorded and listened to. They basically pick you to pieces on everything you are doing wrong when they never trained you on what to do right in the first place. Some, not all, managers are discouraging. They don't help they hinder.

-Some, not all, managers are micro-managers. Will keep tabs on how many calls you make, emails you made, saleforce activity, etc. 

-For the short year I was there, they tried and failed to hire and maintain the Director of Admissions role about 3 times. All either had either been fired or quit. That gives you a clue on how upper management treats their employees. 

-If you were unlucky enough to be placed with one of the brainwashed managers, you had to deal with their sneaky, conniving, and belittling attitude. There was absolutely no trust, no praise, and no respect toward their team. 

-Upper management pressured lower level managers to keep a Nazi like culture: not a second late, business professional clothing (no pants that had pockets on the rear b/c they look like jeans even though the pants are in no way jean material, no leggings under dresses even though our office was non-student facing), no cups/food/snacks of any kind on your desk, no more than 4 pictures in your cube, no Christmas decorations of any kind, etc etc etc.

-Absolutely no day to day perks. Not even a lick of coffee. Do you know how rich this school is? Try 40+ buildings in SF and the newly acquired (old Exploritorium) building next to the Palace of Fine Arts. yeah....

job_title: Online Video Department in San Francisco, CA
pros: The main pro of this company was that there was some flexibility to allow for some great work/life balance, including working from home.  But, they started cracking down on that in 2014.  Once that was gone, there was no reason to stay at this place because the cons were very big.
cons: Toxic work environment.  Management philosophy from the top down is to abuse employees.  Homophobic and ethnic slurs were common from management in my department (and HR consistently refused to address complaints about this).  Also, pay is very low.  And the shady ethics of the school's profiteering and overly aggressive recruiting is widely publicized.

review_title: Not the best place to work -- maybe if you need experience?
job_title: Student Services Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Pay isn't terrible
-Free class per semester (which is great if you can make time for it)
-Great software
-Nice facilities that you get to tour when you've just started
-Great discounts
-Accessible by BART and MUNI, right at Civic Center since I worked at the building on Hayes
-A lot of the students I spoke with are really great people
cons:
-Student retention is difficult for them because of how expensive tuition is for students.
-Management claims to care about students, but really only care about retaining them in order to keep their accreditation (which was on the rocks when I was there).
-Management trains advisors to push students who can't afford it to enroll in courses and they really push hard to meet summer enrollment goals. I felt more like an enrollment manager than a student services advisor when I was there. The truth is, students won't graduate on time if they don't take 2 courses per summer semester, but summer courses are all out of pocket for students. Additionally, students who are no longer eligible for Financial Aid because they've failed their courses are pushed to keep enrolling and paying for these courses out-of-pocket even though they'll probably fail again, all to meet goals (pretty shady business practice, right?).
-Additionally, there's a lot of pushback from management when students drop summer classes. Advisors are often asked to call students and to push them to enroll, even when students give them pretty good reasons for dropping courses. Instead of training advisors in advising techniques to build plans for students that work for them, they're mostly asked to use sales tactics to get students to enroll.
-The institution does not feel like a 'student first' organization, but rather an enrollment/money-making institution. Some students come in with zero art background and limited resources to succeed. The organization attempts to explain itself by saying that it's trying to be accessible to anyone who wants to be in the arts. It seems great, but with so many online students, it's almost impossible for them to connect with their resources.
-Another shady practice: students are only able to transfer credits coming in. If they ever leave and return, they're not able to transfer any more of their credits, even if they're basic college classes and not art classes.
-Ethics aside, the work environment is not that welcoming. It often doesn't feel like a team, and there's no real human feeling to the workplace, such as team lunches. It's mostly, "Here are lists of students you need to call by this time."
-The environment is very much a telemarketing one. There's no real privacy, even when meeting with students, and you're unable to make a connection with your students. 
-Definitely no professional development and mentorship.
-Extremely inflexible work schedule. There was no budging to the 9-6 schedule, unless MAYBE you've been there for a while, regardless of your commute. They put business needs over employee needs without hesitation.

review_title: Good transitional job, but not a career job.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:

- Holiday party is nice?
cons:
- Too low stress. I feel as though my brain and body is turning into a blob surfing the Internet all day.
- REALLY rigid time off policies. Very minimal amount of PTO (legally the least amount of days you are allowed to give to employees).
- You create the office culture yourself. If you have a great team then you can make your own fun ie. potlucks, group trips, etc. Unfortunately I hear we are a rare case and most teams are  generally unhappy with their interactions of their environment (from what I've heard). I lucked out and got a cool manager who doesn't micromanage. Can't speak that for most other teams.
- Insurance sucks. I paid $300 to get my blood drawn. Seriously? If you have dependents, the insurance is TERRIBLE.

- Not a whole lot of advancement opportunities.

review_title: Great people, lousy pay, and benefits
