review_title: Academic staff receive little connection or support from the school's executive leadership
job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: As an instructor, there is very little quality control. This can be good because you have a great deal of freedom in the classroom. Having an academic role at AAU can become very relaxed and hands-off. It is difficult to get fired, unless you make an egregious error that catches the president's attention. For that reason, it can be to your advantage if the president doesn't know you exist; you may never lose your job if you just keep your head down.
cons:
Directors don't have the authorization to promote their high-performance staff, offer them raises, or hire new people. Every such decision must be approved by the president in person; and because the organization has become so large, these requests tend to get ignored. So it can begin feeling like a dead-end career over time. 

Whereas the president retains all the decision-making power, the school has become too large for one person to manage. So it is very difficult to gain promotions based on superior performance, unless you happen to know the president personally. This also means your salary and title will likely remain stagnant for many years, regardless of how well or how poorly you perform. Instructors who have been on staff the longest are at high risk of being paid less than new recruits who are hired under pressure to fill positions. As a result of the above, the work environment tends not to reward high-level performance.  
Hiring standards can be low, when the compensation offered is uncompetitive with industry salaries.
 
I have sensed that high-level management positions are often reserved for people who come from the president's social circle.

Certain departments appear to given more favoritism by the president than others. As a result, some departments are flush with resources, while others remain anemic. 

Directors have no real decision-making ability with regard to how their department is managed. Decisions are often handed down by the president without consulting the director, or fully undertanding how these decisions will impact the department. The decision-making of the president seems more focused on matters of marketing than by academic excellence or quality of instruction.

job_title: ESL Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: The Academy offers flexibility in terms of schedules and class availability. The instructors and staff are committed, cooperative, knowledgeable, and enjoyable to work with.
cons: Many of the students, especially the international students, don't seem committed to learning, are not serious, or don't have clear professional goals, so many drop out. This can be frustrating.

job_title: Campus Safety Officer in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are many pros to this job, the few that really stand out to me is the simplicity of the job, the environment, and the management is on top of everything considering the amount of buildings that have to be secure.
cons: The cons that I can really say about the job is that it can be really boring sometimes which is really just up to the employee and their work ethic.

job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Location: Heart of downtown San Francisco, you cannot complain.
-Students: Students are the lifeblood of AAU, they almost make the job worth taking but you can't pay bills with good feelings.
-Co-workers: Instructors come and go at phenomenal speed, but those who stick around really are on top of their game. Shame it's only other instructors and students who recognize this.
-Creative Environment: We are all artists, and the Academy does provide useful facilities and fills them with creative minds.
-Directors: Some departments have it rough, thankfully I get to report to some of the more friendly and professional folks.
cons:
-Upper Management: Even as a student it was clear that the magic happened at the Student-Teacher level. There is minimal communication from Instructors to Department leads, and Upper Management hides in a castle far, far away dropping edicts and fighting lawsuits.

-No Opportunities: There is an unspoken barrier at 20 hours a week and very little opportunity to move into a full-time position, even if desired and proven that you can do what is required. A part time position is wonderful if you have a flourishing freelance career, otherwise it just gets in the way of other job opportunities.

-Under-compensation: Strictly paid for only in-class hours with no regard for the time it takes to grade and give proper feedback, respond to constant emails or keep up to date with the latest tools. Class hours are too short for the material alone, never mind grading or feedback for students.

Overworked: Part time instructors work just as much or more than full time employees for half the pay, and none of the benefits.

-Contractually barred from teaching elsewhere: Most adjunct/ part time positions are capable of providing a livable wage by allowing instructors to teach anywhere else. AAU forbids it.

-Every Part time instructor is on unemployment 3 months out of the year, and possibly underemployment for the full year: It is impossible to live on a part time income alone, and extremely difficult to find supplemental work due to constantly changing schedules, classes falling mid-day, every day, only being truly available 3 months out of the year. One month at a time, of course. Renders instructors completely unhireable.

review_title: This company cares nothing about retaining valuable employees or it's student's success. It is a for profit University.

job_title: Professional Services in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you enjoy working in San Francisco, this is a good place to start. The Academy is known to have an empire estate all over San Francisco. The company does take pride in its students which is key considering they are an educational institution, and there are many events showcased which shows the Academy has grown over the years to all areas of arts, media and entertainment.
cons: Pay can be mediocre if you are a regular employee. A good place to get your foot in the door to make a living, but I honestly can't see myself there forever. Benefits are okay. If you are single, you don't pay too much each month for your benefits. But when you add your spouse or children, the monthly amounts sky rocket! I feel like nearly my entire paycheck is just going toward these monthly amounts. On top of that, the benefits itself is not very strong since I have to pay a large amount toward my health care services. Work-life balance depends on which department you work for... considering how business is done here, I'm not surprised there is high turnover.

cons: - Number of vacation days

review_title: Online Dept positions can be  rewarding, but upper management, ill-conceived policies & tools, will drive you away
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
If you are interested in the visual arts, it's a great place to get exposure if you work in the online department, where -- working with subject matter experts -- you are exposed to a range of disciplines from illustration & fashion to computer animation and motion picture development.

There may be limited work-from-home options available in the Online Department if you have earned the trust and/or respect of upper management and proven yourself with several years of service.

There is job stability in the production department. There is constantly a need to build new courses and rebuild older courses to keep them current, so there's no shortage of work to go around. [Note:  However, I've seen significant cyclical turnover (people quitting their positions) due to poor decisions made my management, which drove employees away]

The production staff is composed mostly of great team players, several of whom excel at their work and make you want  to perform better, too!
cons:
Consistently abysmal experience with upper management, who was out of touch with the production staff. Upper management fostered a fear-based culture as the best way to keep employees in line -- you never knew when someone might get in trouble, and what minor issue might be blown up out of proportion to trigger it. Those that lasted the longest in their positions were those who kept their heads down and did their best to go unnoticed.  If an employee excelled -- it was unlikely to be recognized. However, on the flip side, new and changing policies were not communicated to staff clearly or effectively; sometimes, they seemed to be created on a whim by upper management.  Thus, several employees received 'verbal warnings' and 'write-ups' for minor infractions. Oftentimes, these were in situations for which the employee, and his/her supervisor, had no idea any 'policy' was being violated (!). 

In any given deadline cycle, most of the production staff  (both content editors and instructional designers) were often juggling unsustainable workloads. New, ill-conceived policies and procedures were often implemented; these involved the generation of excessive busy work. Several times, these policies were delivered close to a deadline, forcing everyone to adapt at the last minute, while already dealing with a heavy load. When the production staff would communicate these concerns again & again to upper and middle managers, the response was acknowledged but not addressed.

Constructive criticism to improve the work environment was discouraged and could incur the ire of management; so it was better to keep your mouth shut. This was unfortunate, since a) it discouraged top performers on the production side to excel, and b) discouraged innovators to improve the tools and systems used to execute their jobs. My peers and I regularly overheard upper management boasting to others about their successes -- with, usually, no recognition of those employees who ensured their perceived successes. 

There is no clearly defined pathway for career advancement, nor is there any rewards system in place for top performers at the ground level. The performance review process is opaque, at best. Staff undergoing reviews aren't typically invited to participate by summarizing their achievements or giving feedback. If the employee is fortunate, he or she may have a supervisor who gives feedback regularly on his/her performance, but this is not the norm.

In many instances, for any given project, PROFIT rules over quality. There were many course projects that were underdeveloped. lacked polish, or were incomplete but still launched in the interest of money.

review_title: Good For Some, Not For Others
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Many of the Administrative positions are a good fit for someone who wants a stable job wherein he/she will typically work an 8 hour day 5 days per week and steadily receive a paycheck every two weeks.

The company offers standard benefits to full-time employees.

If your passion is related to sales, management, department directing, administration, teaching or academic coaching at a for-profit art & design university the Academy may be a good fit.

For the most part, the Academy hires excellent people.  Intelligent, committed, diligent, caring, ambitious, creative, social, and capable employees.

At the Academy you have the opportunity to work with amazing Directors, teachers and students who are passionate about art & design.
cons:
Unless your goal is to become a manager and/ or director of the department you start in (opportunities open infrequently), rather than upward mobility you will have lateral mobility (i.e. the opportunity to change from one department to another).  Advancement and earning-growth opportunities are limited.

In general, employees are treated as assets, rather than team members.  Detached.  Machine-like.  The work environment is not progressive or flexible.  The benefits are good but not great. The focus is on providing an excellent experience for students and furthering the Academy's objectives.  The focus is not on ensuring employees have the best possible working experience, benefits, quality of life, etc.  The goal seems to be that employees have a standard experience.

There is a sense of distrust, resentment and fear among many employees and management.  This may be, in part, the result of high-turnover, actively fear-based management strategies, a lack of integrity regarding what is said by management to employees, and vice versa, and what is done.

Employees are held to the highest standards and are consistently stretched to complete exceptionally heavy workloads and continually meet tight deadlines.  #1 advice:  Whatever position you're in, ask yourself, "In the long-term, will I get (meeting personal goals, quality of life, retirement, etc.) as much as I invest in time, energy, etc.? Is this the best opportunity for my success or is there a better opportunity for my personal goals and quality of life elsewhere?"  If the answers point to a career at the Academy, great.  If not, you may want to rethink working at the Academy. 

The administrative building is old, dusty (from air vents) and dreary.  It probably meets health & safety, "standards."  It doesn't matter if you wipe the dust from your desk it will lightly coat your desk the next day. The dust activates people's allergies.  On the bright side, there are nice windows with good lighting on the perimeters.

Some other cons include lack of effective management,  lack of flexibility, resistance to change, micromanagement, burnout and a corporate style.

review_title: 3 People Quit in Less Than 2 months

review_title: Worst place I have ever worked.
job_title: Administrative in San Francisco, CA
pros:
You get to work in San Francisco, although your pay won't be enough to live there.
Most of the rank-and-file employees are nice people and keep you sane.
One free course per semester for all full-time employees.
Generally good work-life balance for most employees.
cons:
Academy of Art University is a for-profit school that has been run by the same family for three generations. It is essentially a real estate empire that has a school as its tenant. The president, the most recent family boss, makes all decisions and generally does not seem interested in input from her subordinates. The Academy has settled with the City of San Francisco for running afoul of zoning laws for many years, and is currently charged in a federal lawsuit for illegal student recruiting tactics.

The Academy offers a bare minimum of compensation and benefits, and little room for advancement, except to "yes men" types who are fine with never having their own opinion. This results in a lot of entry-level employees who don't stick around, so there's generally a lack of institutional knowledge in all departments. As a full-time employee, you'll get 10 days of vacation time per year, non-negotiable, and you're not allowed to take unpaid time off. You will get none of the fringe benefits that are commonplace at other SF companies - not even free coffee. There is a holiday party every year where you have about 10/1000 odds of winning something like an iPad or a trip by playing bingo, and this is viewed by management as something that we should all appreciate in lieu of competitive compensation.

Middle managers have no liberty to make improvements on their own, so they end up sounding like apologists for the executive office. It all adds up to a toxic and stagnant work environment where too many people tolerate what's going on because they don't know how much better life could be if they worked at virtually any other company.

review_title: Only pay for actual instruction. No pay for prep or office hours.

review_title: Great place to work if you don't mind being emotionally abused on a daily basis
job_title: "Assistant" in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Hostile work environment. Don't be fooled by recruiter's lies!
job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: - The best part about this job is the co-workers, I have found great friends here.
cons:
Terrible work culture, terrible management/directors who only care about money and numbers. Absolutely no transparency. This is a family owned for-profit business. I don’t know about the rest of the "school" but Admissions is the worst job I've ever had! On average there are about 70-80 admissions reps, the real title they SHOULD use for this position is telemarketers or recruiters. They lied to us since day one about the position; they made it look like we were going to be admissions advisers. All throughout one month of training they never told us what exactly we were expected to do on a daily bases. Once started working we were told we are REQUIRED to make 70+ calls a day outbound and about 20 inbound calls.  Managers micromanage you like children to make sure you meet those goals. Before each semester, they make you sign a paper on how many registered students you will bring in. This is straight up sales job and it is illegal by Department of Education standards (or it should be) but they still do all of this while their HR department denies the whole thing. All of your calls are recorded and they give you feedback during your “coaching session” with your manager because you have to follow a certain script. Since we all had already gone through hell passing training exams, we thought we would stay at the job and see how it goes, what a huge MISTAKE. If you are intelligent and outspoken they will make sure they find an excuse to get rid of you. They don’t like feedback!!  They fire people left and right without any warnings.
For the most part, this is a transitional job for everyone; they either hire people fresh out of college so they don't know any better how real professional jobs are supposed to be, or people without college degree!! That’s right they hire people without college degrees to advise students about getting higher education and go to college, WHAT A JOKE!! More like a car salesmen job. Forget about promotions or trying to move up, It is SOLELY based on favoritism. There is no room for growth. 
There is a lot of harassment by the management in many ways; the directors and HR will never do anything about it. They have been in a lot of legal trouble before and I am sure there is more to come!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Longstanding Institution which provides opportunities for students and faculty to flourish in a vibrant cutting edge environment.
cons: Recent bad press. Inaccurate and biased.  The students and faculty deserve to have their merits and efforts shared to turn this around. Inter Department dialog could be encouraged more.

review_title: This place is going downhill fast...
job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in Denver, CO
pros:
-This was a great place for newly graduated students to get a taste of a  real "grown up job". 
-Work life balance is actually great! Once it turns 6:00 pm, all employees literally run out of the building as if the building is on fire. Everyone can't wait to leave.
-I really loved my colleagues. You really end up bonding over the horrible atmosphere that is Academy of Art University.
cons:
-The micromanagement of Upper Management is off the charts! Upper management not only walk the halls to ensure you are on the phone all day, but they actually hide out next to your office door to spy on your conversations and critique your phone calls! (As a side note, I always wondered why these C titles didn't have anything better to do with their time)

-Raises are non existent. They have a potential 3% raise, but no one actually gets 3%. The average raise is 1% for all Admissions representatives. (And no, there are no bonuses.)

-No 401k matching (FYI they blamed the withdrawal of 401k matching on the Admissions Department due to "low enrollment")

-Higher Education is going downhill fast. The rapid decline of student registration in the last 2 years (along with that Forbes article) shows the lack on interest in this school by potential students. More and more individuals will be choosing the cheaper and option of a Community College.

-Goals: there are goals. Even though management states that there are not "registration goals", this is not completely true. Goals can be upheld without management overtly stating, "You need to hit your registration goal of X!" They will place Reps on "PIP" (or performance improvement plans) which is another way to track, degrade and humiliate Reps into getting more applications and registrations. Constant micromanagement regarding the number of phone calls made a day (60 is the minimum), hours of "talk time" (10 a week min) and weekly Application/Registration submissions (3 a week) borderlines on illegal. Although they legally do not give incentives for doing well in these areas, they will place Reps on these "PIP" plans to either improve their performance or try to get those people to leave. 

-There is no growth within this company. None. Once we had an individual  who successfully climbed up the corporate ladder only to be fired after 3 days of returning early from her Maternity leave. 

-Academy of Art does not care about its students. Once processed through the 5 weeks of school, Admissions is required to pass off students to "Student Service Advisors" who's job is only to register students into their 2nd semester and NOTHING else. With little support system, students tend to drop off after their first 5 weeks and then end responsible for "Tuition Forfeiture". Which means they owe Academy of Art 100% of their first semester tuition even if they only attended class a couple of times. 
And don't forget that if a full time onsite student drops down to 3 classes instead of 4 at any time (and for any reason) in their semester, he or she WILL be kicked out of the dorms. Regardless of if he/she already paid $7k for their dorm room.

review_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative: Few Bright Spots Overshadowed by Horrible Management
job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in Pickering, ON
pros: Superb facilities, inspiring student stories, passionate faculty, and a terrific introduction to building sales and account management skills. Extravagant Christmas party gets everyone excited at the end of the year. Originally accessible, now beautiful work location centered in San Francisco. Employees also get to take a free class at AAU per semester. The role also makes for great work life balance as work does not go home with you whatsoever and you have one hour of lunch daily.
cons:
Poor practices, high turnover, and meager benefits define working for Admissions management. We aggressively target students that can't afford a measly $50 in fees to take on an education of $110,000+ regardless of their financial aid status. We are dishonest by refusing to provide our low graduation rates even when students ask directly. We have multiple accreditations in "probationary" status and try not to advertise that we're sliding further from being in good standing..

There are so many strange practices: HR tells staff to change departments but keep it a secret from their managers. People are laid off due to having their positions eliminated only to have the same position filled a month later. The team is promised new titles effective 2015, but it is never honored. Our computer activity and number of phone calls are constantly monitored. Some staff are fired for being late 8 times while others are late 20 times without losing their jobs. Some staff are denied the chance to interview while others don't even have to interview to get promoted. Some of us work hard to get the perfect "PCG" score towards our raise, only to find out at the end of our year that this is no longer valid and that we'll be graded on new, undetermined standards. No business will ever be perfect, but these clear examples show that in Admissions, even the most basic of business practices can't be run properly. Staff turnover is high and we recently had 11 supervisors/managers/directors across several key departments quit within a 2 month span, leaving only a couple leaders to manage the shrinking department. It is not normal to have all of your leaders leave at once, and illustrates that the upper management of AAU does not know how to retain.

The minimal benefits provided to us were removed this year- 401k matching was cancelled due to the school's failing performance and we didn't even get a day off to observe July 4th. With the company being dishonest to students and staff, cutting benefits and roles due to failing company performance, and failing to address employee feedback year after year, what reason do we as staff have to remain loyal to this company? No brainer here: there's really nothing left!

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in Montreal, QC
pros: Steady income. The chance to take a course for free each semester and attend major events such as fashion shows and the annual Spring Show, where students' work is showcased. Great camaraderie between colleagues. No overtime, no homework, no extreme stress at the office. The relationship one builds with students and their parents is very satisfying. To see your students start school and thrive for success is the best part of the job.
cons: Each department works independently from one another and as an employer of its own, so I can only speak in regards to the Admissions Department, unfortunately. The leadership does ok with driving sales through enrolling students left and right, regardless if they have little to no art experience or can afford this pricey college education of more than $110K for a BFA. They pressure the employees to make the numbers: 3 Applications per week, 2 Registrations per week. If one does not meet these expectation for lack of good prospects, they pull you in to the office for formal coaching on performance. They are constantly telling the employees what they need of them, but spend little to no time on giving them the resourses to succeed, such as training, role plays, on the spot feedback, team selling, etc. They don't even monitor calls anymore for quality assurance and training purposes, which was annoying, but was pretty effective. The department does not provide employees with a policies and proceedures guide or a standard yearly review, so one never receives a formal appraisal nor the chance to receive a raise. It is diminishing and depressing to work for the Admissions Management. They will never acknowledge ones hard work through recognition nor promotions. My manager gets late to the office everyday without even saying good morning, and stays in his office without interacing with his team, unless it is to give you a message or to coach you on your below average numbers on a given week. I've had better leadership and growth opportunities working in fast foods and retail. If you are ok with having a dead end job, with little to no intelectual stimulation, go ahead and accept their $50,000 a year offer (it might be enticing, but on the long run you will learn that it's still not enough for the cost of living in the Bay Area). The facilities and working conditions are a disgrace and border line degrading. Spoiler alert: the building is in the Fisherman's Warf, which is a tourist trap and half an hour away from downtown and most of the train stations. Good luck taking a lyft or an uber to work everyday (or the shuttle, which has the craziest schedules).

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in Dubai
pros: Colleagues make the work culture - potlucks, outings, friendships.
cons:
You are in a high-volume Call Center capacity. You are stuck in cubicles with a headset dialing phone numbers all day. You may even get hung up on or yelled at with profane language.
Turnover is extremely high, but some people are swayed by the high starting salary. Others have left within a week of training because the Call Center culture is not disclosed to them.
There are three levels of working for the Admissions Department - Representative, Lead, Manager. Candidates are considered for the next "level" if someone leaves their post. It is not merit-based, but more so who you know as those holding these positions have cliques helping others move up.
You are told it is not about numbers, but you are sent Weekly Reports showing your productivity. You are questioned when your numbers are not high enough.
Working hard gets you as far as someone who makes the minimum amount of calls and has low productivity. If you go above and beyond, you will have more responsibility but you are not compensated for this. It is also not factored into your raise/if you receive a raise.
Leaving the company is openly discussed as people take this platform as a stepping stone for their next venture and deal with it as best they can.
The work is simple and monotonous but you are berated (depending on your manager).

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Meet great students with true passion for Art and Design.
-My peers were awesome once you comb through the fake representatives that cause high school drama. 
-79 New Montgomery is in a great location. Close to Bart and great restaurants.
cons:
-The job description is totally misleading; in a nutshell, this is a sales position and your job is threatened once you don't produce applications and class-registrations.
-You have inbound and outbound call goals, and a talk time goal; your call traffic is monitored and once you stop producing, management will nit-pick your call quality to fire you. 
-There's a huge disconnect between the for-profit mentality and the best interests of students; this becomes discouraging when students later drop because they were pressured into registering for classes when in reality they were not a good fit to begin with. Managers make you call students multiple times a day, and have them apply. 
-The university will not hesitate getting rid of you, or move you around to create a hostile work environment to later lure you into resignation.
-They really don't offer a 401k; you can sign up for one but they don't match it - yet they fly higher management all over the country for their commute on university budget.

job_title: Teacher in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Wish no stars was an option.
job_title: Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working with the some of the students is great; quite possibly the only real pro of the job. Though most of the kids are nasty, entitled little cake-eaters, so that kind of negates my point.
cons:
Laughably low pay for the industry, and don't even think of negotiating a higher rate; i was told my rate was not up for negotiations, and i will take it or leave it.

Terrible benefits, and if you have a family it gets unbelievably expensive.  

The school used to encourage staff and faculty to use equipment for enrichment, but now that is considered "theft," and you will be terminated for that. 

Sustained culture of fear, conniving administration, and an ineffectual CEO that doesn't know the first thing about education.  She couldn't run a McDonald's, let alone a university.  

In fact, this place is a McDonald's, culture-wise. Constant pushing of being "customer service oriented," and calling the students "customers," is probably one of the most abhorrent things about this place. 

The security team is made up of petty bullies and lackeys that will make your life there needlessly difficult.  These jokers alternate between being completely incompetent to being a wannabe Sturmabteilung.

The administration really couldn't care at all about providing adequate equipment, they only care about money. If you try buying anything to improve the quality of education, it gets shot down, or they will approve the cheapest items, and leave important parts out. in my case, they approved the batteries for a new item, but not the actual item. I thought: "wow. do they even look at what they are doing?"

Another interesting fact of dealing with purchasing and the administration is that they did not approve a $20.00 first aid kit for my office, because that was to be bought by myself on my own dime.  i submitted a request for this same kit over and over again, until i was told by my dept.'s Executive Director to stop trying to get it. I am sure OSHA would love that. 

They claim "we all have to wear multiple hats" as an excuse to continually pile more and more work unrelated to your job description, because they can. they wanted me to become a statistician in edition to the management position i was already doing.  i asked for them to train me properly on metrics, and they balked.  

Your fellows will not hesitate to throw you under the bus, like they did to me.

Oh, and the past year's low enrollment is YOUR fault.

...Before he left, my former boss told me: "don't even try with this place." He was totally spot-on.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA

Abusive micromanagement style in many departments. This place is the definition of a hostile work environment.

This isn't a business, it's a posse for a reality-television-star-wanna-be CEO who has the ethics of Richard Nixon crossed with the empathy of Attila the Hun.

If you are even moderately healthy, the benefits are worse than what you could get on the open market

review_title: P R O S P E C T I V E   E M P L O Y E E S   B E W A R E:
job_title: Instructional Designer in San Francisco, CA
pros: i am sure that the founder of the school had very good intentions. he started the school in 1929. unfortunately, he is gone and it has been handed down to people who evidently do not share his original mission.
cons:
i took a huge pay cut to take the job. the salaries are ridiculously low, especially in san francisco. at first i did not mind since i thought it was an academic environment. i was wrong. this is a for-profit university, with emphasis on profit. 

ironically none of that profit finds its way to the employees. we were all overworked and underpaid. full-time instructors there have huge course loads. it sounded as if it was at least 2-3 times the load that a professor would carry in another institution. how can you give your best when you don't have the time? 

i was given the strong impression that quantity and production were far more important than quality. this did not sit well with me. i am a thorough person and i knew that the students were counting on me. i could not let them down. as a result, i was constantly badgered and encouraged to "cut corners" everywhere i could. 

 have been told that they own more property in san francisco than any other entity. there is also that flashy car museum. people have made the joke that it is a real estate company with a school attached to it for the tax breaks.

job_title: Online Help Desk Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros: I like that the Online Education Department has about 7 different teams that constantly interact with each other to create the best online classroom experience for our students.
cons: At this time I do not have any cons to mention.

review_title: Toxic workplace and very Condescending Management
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Met coworkers who became great friends
cons: Salary they pay is too low vs. the demand of work but that’s not even the reason for high turnover; it’s how management treat people. HR is a revolving door because no can stand the leadership. Instead of coaching, mentoring & showing support to staff, they would continue to dump workload without checking if you’re still ok, blame you if something didn’t go as planned or you said things differently than what they dictated because that’s their management style — authoritative & micromanaging. They ask questions that makes you feel stupid when in reality, it’s the lack of guidance & training that hinders one’s growth & potential. They would make you feel worse about yourself & kill your confidence. Some of my peers applied for promotion & were initially turned down due to “gaps in skills” & because they require “1 year of service” which are just clearly BS as they have promoted a staff in the past who’s been there for less than a year & no training was extended to them so they can have the chance to close the “gaps” to move up to the next level. When they promoted staff, it’s not because they finally saw their great potentials but because they can’t hire anyone. As a result, my peers  didn’t feel any sincerity in their promotion & left the company afterwards. The management are insecure people & enjoys making their staff feel like they don’t have any place to go. An average of 1-2 resignation per month recently became 1 resignation per week; that’s how bad it is. People who leave don’t turn in 2 week notice due to fear of retaliation which they’re very good at. Personally, I was harassed when I turned in my resignation. They don’t value people. They only value themselves as higher ups gets paid really well but the staff’s salary is really insulting.

review_title: Job is heavily based on outbound phone calls. You are not required to reach a "minimum" with enrollment/registration.
job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Expectations are straight forward. Coaching is based on your recorded calls. Pay is great considering that the job itself isn't stressful. You don't bring your work home which allows for a work/life balance.
cons: Can get repetitive: expectation of 70-80 outbound dials per day. No commission or bonus structure.

job_title: Campus Host in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are flexible work hours/work days. For a job just to get some money it pays well and is easy
cons: Managers do not care about the staff members. There is a constant feeling that management does not know what is going on and does not care. Very unorganized. No career opportunities.

job_title: Undergrad Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Mainly three things come to mind. 
Part of admissions used to be stationed in downtown SF and the convenience of both getting to work and running errands on "lunch" was pretty great. Also, connecting with people who were aspirating artists made the day to day different since you got to hear some cool stories and backgrounds. Lastly, the people that I was lucky enough to work with made all the difference in making this place worth it.
cons: Even before current management took hold, there was a lot of miscommunication between admissions and other school departments which could potentially jeopardize the student from even enrolling. Also, I would have to included how inefficient some of the daily tasks were such as # of outbound/inbound calls or talk time when it should not take hours to explain simple info to potential students. However, upper management has turned into a type of frat house, bro culture where teams are divided and groups become selective; not to mention the endless "big guy/buddy/bro" encouragement pep talks that seemed to come out of managements mouth like word vomit. Lastly, the combination of cost and course difficulty made this school a bad fit for a lot of students and having to enroll your "goal" of students every week made it seem like nonsense after a while. This place is like 30% school and 70% business; also moving admissions to the Cannery was dumb.

job_title: Human Resources in San Francisco, CA
pros: Amazing co-workers who remained friends even after separation with the organization.
cons:
•	Lack of interest in the development of employees and zero employee retention efforts
•	Zero transparency
•	Elitist, snooty and hierarchal culture of the executive team. A manager refuses to “deal with people”.
•	Promote employees out of necessity
•	Executive team in general tends to be disrespectful of staff. You will definitely feel like “just a body in the office needed to get tasks done”.
•	VPs and Execs are paid well, some even receive housing allowances, but the rest are paid way below market value for San Francisco Bay Area.
•	Condescending style of managers make you feel stupid and fearful of being called out or written up.
•	Relevant training does not exist. 
•	Different standards per employee; for example, the staff are told not to wear leggings since it is not business casual but managers may  come to work in leggings all the time.
•	Most employees who have left the HR team this year – approximately 1-2 per month – gave little to zero notice of resignation due to fear of retaliation. Because there is a large amount of work that needs to be done, management tends to “dump” unrealistic workload/expectations to employees up until their last working hour.
•	HR management has a reverential treatment towards execs and department directors/VPs.
•	Morale couldn’t possibly go any lower.

pros: Very nice people work here.
cons:

job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Co-workers are supportive of one another.
cons:
I worked at AAU for two years and I didn’t realize how toxic it was until I left. Firstly, the hourly rate is very low. Secondly, there’s no office spirit or team morale. I’ve never seen Dr. Stephens once my whole tenure. That sad excuse of a pumpkin pie they hand out every Thanksgiving should not excuse her absence. Thirdly, there’s a lack of communication between departments that leads to confusion and misleading information given to students. It creates resentment between departments. Finally, management is very hypocritical. They preach that they want to promote people and foster growth within the company, but they prevent it at every turn. During my time, three people on my team applied to transfer to a different department; they were top performers. My department director prevented it at every turn and cited their lack of movement as a “business need.” Because there was such a high turnover rate, the director was fearful no one would be left on the team. So those three people became trapped and they left two months later. 

When I was up for a promotion with a possibility to transfer to another department, they threatened, “If they offer you a position on their team, I will deny the transfer because I need you on this team. It’s a business need.” I left a month later. I’ll never forget that they said that. 

If you ever interview at AAU and management brags that they encourage upward mobility within the company, don’t believe them. I did and it was a mistake.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Building upon its long-past reputation, the declining  AAU is still maintaining a great environment to meet fellow artists... for now...
cons:
The Stephens Family (owner of the private university) has crafted an environment that puts the bottom line above the student’s best interests, including hiring unqualified staff.  Their faculty “business model” relies on hiring passionate industry professionals, which is good.  However they are largely low-paid and part-time, which results in having them personally fill the gaps of the school to acccommodate the base needs of their students, ranging from basic departments resources, to unpaid time expectations.  

One-way management dictates few rights for both their staff and faculty employees, down to their loophole-based contracts; they skirt insurance requirements by having “Technicians” sign up for 8-days-less than the legal requirement needed to offer insurance to part time employees, (contract) however expect the standards of part-time employees on all other counts.  

I was regular witness to management skirting state-mandated hourly wage requirements by “requesting” employees to work past their 40/hrs week standard, yet not offer the legally required compensation of overtime, thus creating a revolving door of turnover due to burnout.
